description: The Apple Certified Associate certification is an excellent starting point for people working with Apple Mac systems in a networked environment. The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. This certification course was previously titled Mac Integration Basics.
descriptionMD: The Apple Certified Associate certification is an excellent starting point for people working with Apple Mac systems in a networked environment. The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. This certification course was previously titled Mac Integration Basics.
name: ACA Mac Integration Basics 10.13
subtitle: Apple Certified Associate

episodes.description: The Apple Certified Associate certification is an excellent starting point for people working with Apple Mac systems in a networked environment. The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. This certification course was previously titled Mac Integration Basics.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.596
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.596 --> 00:00:07.460
Hello, and thank you for watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.460 --> 00:00:11.390
We're talking with Don Pezet about
Apple Certified Associate, a new series.

4
00:00:11.390 --> 00:00:13.420
Don, tell us about this series.
>> All right, well,

5
00:00:13.420 --> 00:00:16.770
in this series we're gonna be taking
a look at Apple technologies from

6
00:00:16.770 --> 00:00:20.330
the perspective of somebody who
has to work with them everyday.

7
00:00:20.330 --> 00:00:24.940
This is designed as a kind of a first
step in your Apple certification career.

8
00:00:24.940 --> 00:00:26.960
So we cover a lot basics
that are spread across.

9
00:00:26.960 --> 00:00:28.770
How to use our Mac OS environment.

10
00:00:28.770 --> 00:00:30.980
How to support computer
systems running Mac.

11
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:35.980
And to be thinking about various things
like security initiatives and so on.

12
00:00:35.980 --> 00:00:38.800
As we step through this course
you are gonna see it covers quite

13
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:39.650
a range of material.

14
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:42.000
Probably more than what
a regular end use would need.

15
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:45.080
But it's geared more towards that IT
professional, somebody who is gonna be

16
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:48.350
working with these systems, and
needs to know the ins and outs a little

17
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:51.070
better than the regular end user.
>> So you've already touched on this, but

18
00:00:51.070 --> 00:00:53.780
who else is the show targeted towards?
>> All right, so this is

19
00:00:53.780 --> 00:00:58.010
really targeted towards businesses, people
who support Macs, that's kinda what I

20
00:00:58.010 --> 00:01:01.930
mentioned a moment ago but I said
it's a little more than an end user.

21
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:04.690
Honestly end users can benefit from
a lot of this knowledge as well.

22
00:01:04.690 --> 00:01:08.330
It'll help you better understand how to
use your Mac and some of the features that

23
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:11.990
are tucked behind the scenes that most
of us don't necessarily think about.

24
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:15.590
But the reality is this course
it used to have a name,

25
00:01:15.590 --> 00:01:18.030
Apple used to call this
Mac Integration Basics.

26
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:22.460
And when it was called Mac Integration
Basics, it was focused on teaching you

27
00:01:22.460 --> 00:01:27.100
how to integrate your Mac with
a Microsoft Windows environment.

28
00:01:27.100 --> 00:01:31.190
And so if you work in a business where
you had Mac and Windows machines and

29
00:01:31.190 --> 00:01:34.560
they needed to work together,
this was the course view.

30
00:01:34.560 --> 00:01:35.900
Over the years it's changed a lot.

31
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:38.880
It is still called Mac Integration Basics
on some pages, but

32
00:01:38.880 --> 00:01:41.650
it's really
the Apple Certified Associate now.

33
00:01:41.650 --> 00:01:46.480
And it's focused on anybody who support
Macs in a business environment or

34
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:49.500
is using them in any kind of professional
sense to make sure that they are stable,

35
00:01:49.500 --> 00:01:52.060
secure and up and running.
>> Is there a certification

36
00:01:52.060 --> 00:01:53.380
involved in the course?

37
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:53.940
Absolutely.
So

38
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:55.380
that's where we get the confusion, right?

39
00:01:55.380 --> 00:01:58.990
Because it used to be Mac Integration
Basics, and it was just a course.

40
00:01:58.990 --> 00:02:02.560
Then they added the certification,
the Apple Certified Associate, or ACA.

41
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:04.640
And now, well,

42
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:08.620
there actually used to be more than
one course that could get your ACA.

43
00:02:08.620 --> 00:02:11.140
This is now the only
course that gets your ACA.

44
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:13.150
>> So they merged the two together.

45
00:02:13.150 --> 00:02:15.000
So it used to be kinda this
optional component but

46
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:17.100
now it's all stuck together and
it's one and the same.

47
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:19.710
So when you hear somebody say
Mac integration basics and

48
00:02:19.710 --> 00:02:23.570
you hear somebody say Apple Certified
Associate, those are one and the same.

49
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:25.030
So what we're gonna learn
here in this series,

50
00:02:25.030 --> 00:02:27.500
we're gonna cover all the exam objectives.

51
00:02:27.500 --> 00:02:30.860
To make sure that you have the knowledge
in your noggin to be able to sit down,

52
00:02:30.860 --> 00:02:33.430
take the exam and get ACA certified.

53
00:02:33.430 --> 00:02:35.950
And I mentioned earlier that's
kind of that first step

54
00:02:35.950 --> 00:02:37.500
in the Apple Certification Program.

55
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:41.190
Somebody might choose to continue on to
do Apple Certified Support Professional,

56
00:02:41.190 --> 00:02:43.210
somebody may stop right here at ACA.

57
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:46.930
It's actually a nice cert to be able
to get because it doesn't have a ton of

58
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:50.030
information behind it, so
it's easy to grasp all the data,

59
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:52.140
get that certification and
get that thrown in your resume.

60
00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:55.340
And then you can always choose to
move more advanced down the road.

61
00:02:55.340 --> 00:02:57.040
>> So what sort of episodic topics are we

62
00:02:57.040 --> 00:02:58.350
gonna be covering?
>> All right,

63
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:00.470
we're gonna jump all over the place.

64
00:03:00.470 --> 00:03:04.030
There is still some integration with
Windows that is part of this exam.

65
00:03:04.030 --> 00:03:07.070
And that's actually what we're gonna
start with, directory services.

66
00:03:07.070 --> 00:03:10.800
Connecting a Mac to a Microsoft
active directory environment.

67
00:03:10.800 --> 00:03:13.152
Those are very prevalent out
there in the business world,

68
00:03:13.152 --> 00:03:14.978
almost non existent in the home,
all right.

69
00:03:14.978 --> 00:03:18.090
That's an example of where home users
don't necessarily benefit from this.

70
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:20.040
But in the business world,
they are everywhere.

71
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:21.860
So we'll get a chance
to see how that works.

72
00:03:21.860 --> 00:03:23.690
We're gonna take a look at file sharing.

73
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:27.010
We can share files across the network and
get our Macs talking.

74
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:30.670
We'll do email, contacts, and
calendar or collaboration software.

75
00:03:30.670 --> 00:03:32.630
So if you're in a business environment,

76
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:35.470
you likely have some kind
of centralized mail system.

77
00:03:35.470 --> 00:03:37.480
Maybe calendaring, maybe contacts.

78
00:03:37.480 --> 00:03:42.420
We can integrate all of that right
into Mac OS using the mail, calendar,

79
00:03:42.420 --> 00:03:43.280
and contacts apps.

80
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:45.550
Which are appropriately named for
what they do.

81
00:03:45.550 --> 00:03:46.086
>> [LAUGH]

82
00:03:46.086 --> 00:03:47.498
>> So we'll get a chance to see that.

83
00:03:47.498 --> 00:03:49.435
We're gonna dabble into security and

84
00:03:49.435 --> 00:03:52.660
some of the security features
that are built into Mac OS.

85
00:03:52.660 --> 00:03:54.110
Which are on by default,
some which aren't.

86
00:03:54.110 --> 00:03:57.070
So we'll get the chance to see which
are which and how to work with those.

87
00:03:57.070 --> 00:04:00.680
We'll do printing, because well,
people still print and we need to

88
00:04:00.680 --> 00:04:01.529
>> Do you think it's good?

89
00:04:01.529 --> 00:04:03.523
[LAUGH]
>> Businesses especially,

90
00:04:03.523 --> 00:04:04.950
printing is really important.

91
00:04:04.950 --> 00:04:07.375
We're going to tackle backing up content.

92
00:04:07.375 --> 00:04:08.064
Time Machine.

93
00:04:08.064 --> 00:04:10.400
Time Machine is really easy.

94
00:04:10.400 --> 00:04:12.450
For a home user, it's easy to forget.

95
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:13.940
For a business user, it's essential.

96
00:04:13.940 --> 00:04:15.860
We need to make sure that
we back up our system.

97
00:04:15.860 --> 00:04:17.840
So we'll see how to back it up,
how to restore,

98
00:04:17.840 --> 00:04:20.000
how to make sure that our data
is there when we need it.

99
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:22.960
And if we do have a failure,
that we can recover from it.

100
00:04:22.960 --> 00:04:26.130
And the last thing that we're gonna
tackle is kind of a fun one for

101
00:04:26.130 --> 00:04:29.940
me, which is if you're moving from
the Windows world over to Mac OS,

102
00:04:29.940 --> 00:04:33.490
sometimes there's applications
that still require Windows.

103
00:04:33.490 --> 00:04:37.270
Well, we're gonna see how you can run
those Windows applications on your Mac.

104
00:04:37.270 --> 00:04:39.690
We'll see virtualization
software like VMware Fusion.

105
00:04:39.690 --> 00:04:44.530
And we'll take a look at Boot Camp where
you can actually install Microsoft Windows

106
00:04:44.530 --> 00:04:49.010
on your Mac and have it run side-by-side
with MacOS so that when you boot up you

107
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:53.020
can pick, do I wanna boot up into MacOS or
do I wanna boot up into Microsoft Windows?

108
00:04:53.020 --> 00:04:55.020
And you still have access
to those applications.

109
00:04:55.020 --> 00:04:58.970
Really neat features, and we're gonna see
them all right throughout this series in

110
00:04:58.970 --> 00:05:00.250
Apple Certified Associates.
>> Thank you, Don.

111
00:05:00.250 --> 00:05:03.540
So if Apple Certified Associates sounds
like a course you'd be interested in, and

112
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:04.880
you should be interested in it,

113
00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:07.670
make sure you see all the episodes
from our course library.

114
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:09.858
And thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

115
00:05:09.858 --> 00:05:12.771
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don looks at working with directory services in macOS. He explains what a directory service is and the benefits of using a directory service. He then demonstrates joining a Mac client to an Active Directory domain.
episodes.title: Directory Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses connecting to a network file server using various protocols. He demonstrates how to connect by browsing the network, as well as manually entering the information. He also demonstrates how to enable file sharing and share a folder using macOS.
episodes.title: File Sharing

episodes.description: In this episode, Don looks at how to connect to various collaboration software. He demonstrates connecting to mail servers like Exchange and Office365, as well as non-Windows platforms using IMAP and POP3. He also explains how to connect to calendar services and contact services.
episodes.title: Collaboration Software

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses security features in macOS. He talks about sandboxing and system integrity protection. He also describes library randomization and execute disable.
episodes.title: Security Features

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues his look at security features in macOS. He looks at how the Password Assistant can be used to help generate strong passwords. He also demonstrates multi-factor authentication.
episodes.title: Security Features Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues his look at security features in macOS. He demonstrates how to set a firmware password. He also demonstrates how to lock a Mac screen, set a screen timeout, use fast user switching, and disable automatic logon.
episodes.title: Security Features Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don finishes his dive into the security features of macOS by looking at FileVault full-disk encryption. He then explores VPNs as protection for data-in-motion. Finally he shows you security options for protecting from malicious applications using Gatekeeper and attacks from the network using the macOS Firewall.
episodes.title: Security Features Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores printing with a Mac running High Sierra. He takes you through all the basics like connecting to a USB printer, a network printer, and wireless printers. Then he looks at printer sharing, setting up an IP printer, and specifying printer features.
episodes.title: Printing

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks you through migrating from a Windows PC to a Mac using the Windows Migration Assistant. He explains the procedure for prepping both computers for the migration and then goes into detail on each step to ensure a successful migration.
episodes.title: Moving Content

episodes.description: Description: In this episode, Don shows you how to protect your data using Time Machine. He starts by describing Time Machine's capabilities as a backup solution and then familiarizes you with the working parts and options.
episodes.title: Time Machine

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a look at what options are available when you need to run a Windows application on your Mac. He explains several possible solutions like macOS ported software and open source alternatives. He also explores using virtualization software like VMware's Fusion, to run a Windows virtual machine that will facilitate running Windows native apps.
episodes.title: Running Windows Applications

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores another option for working with Windows native applicationscalled Boot Camp. He explains when and why Boot Camp may be the correct solution for using Windows native apps and then demonstrates how to deploy a Boot Camp system.
episodes.title: Boot Camp

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores another option for working with Windows native applicationscalled Boot Camp. He explains when and why Boot Camp may be the correct solution for using Windows native apps and then demonstrates how to deploy a Boot Camp system.
episodes.title: Boot Camp Part 2
